dt: {bc}to trim off an outside, excess, or irregular part of
{bc}to diminish or reduce by or as if by paring

dt.t: the novel was {it}pared{/it} down to 200 pages

et: Middle English {it}paren,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}parer{/it} "to make, prepare, adorn, trim, cut off," going back to Latin {it}parāre{/it} "to supply, provide, make ready," probably verbal derivative of a nominal base {it}*paro-{/it}, formed from {it}parere{/it} "to give birth to, bring into being, produce" {ma}{mat|parturient|}{/ma}

The Latin verb is alternatively taken as a direct outcome of an Indo-European present formation {it}*pr̥h{inf}3{/inf}-i̯e-,{/it} but the phonetic development has been questioned. Most of the numerous compound verbs formed from {it}parāre,{/it} as {it}apparāre{/it} "to prepare" (see {et_link|apparatus|apparatus}), {it}comparāre{/it} "to prepare, collect, muster," {it}disparāre{/it} "to divide" (see {et_link|disparate|disparate}), {it}praeparāre{/it} "to furnish beforehand, {et_link|prepare|prepare}," {it}reparāre{/it} "to recover, restore" (see {et_link|repair:1|repair:1}), {it}sēparāre{/it} "to divide" (see {et_link|separate:1|separate:1}), fail to show vowel weakening. The verbs {it}imperāre{/it} "to levy, order, command" (see {et_link|emperor|emperor}) and {it}properāre{/it} "to hasten" (perhaps of independent origin) are for uncertain reasons exceptions. The Romance development in sense from "prepare" to a more concrete "cut (the peeling from), trim"—well attested in Old French—has become virtually the only sense in English, with the broader French meaning "prepare, adorn, decorate" being only marginally attested.
shortdef: to trim off an outside, excess, or irregular part of
to diminish or reduce by or as if by paring
